name: Binary Colouring
statement: You are given a positive integer $$$x$$$. Find any array of integers $$$a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1}$$$ for which the following holds: $$$1 \le n \le 32$$$, $$$a_i$$$ is $$$1$$$, $$$0$$$, or $$$-1$$$ for all $$$0 \le i \le n - 1$$$, $$$x = \displaystyle{\sum_{i=0}^{n - 1}{a_i \cdot 2^i}}$$$, There does not exist an index $$$0 \le i \le n - 2$$$ such that both $$$a_{i} \neq 0$$$ and $$$a_{i + 1} \neq 0$$$. It can be proven that under the constraints of the problem, a valid array always exists.
inputFormat: Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line of input contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \le t \le 10^4$$$) — the number of test cases. The description of the test cases follows. The only line of each test case contains a single positive integer $$$x$$$ ($$$1 \le x < 2^{30}$$$).
outputFormat: For each test case, output two lines. On the first line, output an integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \le n \le 32$$$) — the length of the array $$$a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1}$$$. On the second line, output the array $$$a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{n-1}$$$. If there are multiple valid arrays, you can output any of them.
